pages.text: Pseudoangustidontus is a genus of Hurdiid Radiodont from the Early Ordovician of Morocco. The animal, maybe just shy of 1 m long or just above, is the second described Ordovician radiodont from Morocco. Known from a total of 35 different specimens comprising an exhaustive record of its frontal appendages, the animal probably was anatomically close to its cousin Aegirocassis.

The Appendages would bear 6 major endites, each hosting a row (or two) of setae the animal would use to feed.
Much like Aegirocassis, this animal was a filter feeder rather than a macropredator. Despite it's potentially smaller size, Pseudoangustidontus more or less as abundant as Aegirocassis in the analysis conducted for the

study, which was able to identify 44 appendages of this species in a pool of 121 total analysed; of the remaining ones 43 were of Aegirocassis, a further 8 from another unnamed relative of it and another 9 of a non related hurdiid, the remaining appendages were of non sifter-feeding radiodonts. The abundance of frontal appendages was enough to allow pinpointing two different species in the genus, one of which new, and some other nonspecific material.

Like Aegirocassis, Pseudoangustidontus would've been a suspension feeder which would've preyed on mesoplankton, as in organisms between 0.2-20mm, which in the Early Paleozoic would've been trilobitomorphs larvae, agnostid trilobites, ostracods, bradoriids, copepods, malacostracans and branchiopod arthropods, as well as graptolites and chitinozoans.
